Key Arguments: The submission questions the feasibility of ACMA enforcing industry standards without determining the truth of statements, which is fundamental to identifying misinformation and disinformation.
The author argues that the bill implies a paternalistic view of citizens, suggesting that the government believes people need protection from their own interpretations.
The submission criticizes the government's attempt to balance public interest and freedom of speech, suggesting that the government should not interfere in public discourse.
Main Themes: Truth and Determination: Concerns about how misinformation can be addressed without assessing the truth of statements.
Government Overreach: The belief that the government is overstepping by trying to regulate public discourse.
Freedom of Speech: Emphasis on the importance of maintaining freedom of speech without government interference.
Notable Quotes: Truth is fundamental to the definition of mis/dis-information (as is acknowledged in the bill).
This bill serves as evidence that the government views its citizens as children who require protection from their own ability to interpret the world they live in.
The right balance is for the government to keep their arrogant, self-righteous hands out of public discourse.
